In a moment, he thought, the fellows of this guard would come charging out, swords in hand. They could not have failed to hear the struggle on the stairs of stone, he reasoned, for here the noise and confusion of the upper temple was muted to a murmur. Noork At first he saw nothing out of the ordinary. Apparently there was no stir of life along that leaf-shadowed way. And then he caught a glimpse of blurring shadowy shapes, blotches of cottony mist that blended all too well with the foliage. One of the things from the island in the Lake of Uzdon moved, and he saw briefly the bottom of a foot dirtied with the mud of the trail. Noork squinted. So the Misty Ones were not entirely invisible. Pain was growing in his numbed arm now, but as it came so came strength. He climbed further out on the great branch to where sticky and overripe fruit hung heavy. With a grin he locked his legs upon the forking of the great limb and filled his arms with fruit. A barrage of the juicy fruit blanketed the misty shapes. Stains spread and grew. Patchy outlines took on a new color and sharpness. Noork found that he was pelting a half-dozen hooded and robed creatures whose arms and legs numbered the same as his own, and the last remnant of superstitious fear instilled in his bruised brain by the shaggy Vasads vanished. A fat, square-jawed face, harsh lines paralleling the ugly blob of a nose, showed through the opened robe of the leader. The face was that of Doctor Von Mark the treacherous Nazi scientist that Stephen Dietrich had trailed across space to Sekk! But Noork knew nothing of that chase. The man's face seemed familiar, and hateful, but that was all he remembered. "I see you have come from the island," said the Doctor. "Perhaps you can tell me the secret of this invisible material I wear. With the secret of invisibility I, Karl Von Mark, can again conquer Earth and make the Fatherland invincible." "I do not understand too well," said Noork hesitantly. "Are we enemies? There is so much I have forgotten." He regarded the brutal face thoughtfully. "Perhaps you know from what valley the great bird brought me," he said. "Or perhaps the other bird brought you here." Von Mark's blue eyes widened and then he roared with a great noise that was intended to be mirth. His foot slammed harder into Noork's defenseless ribs. "Perhaps you have forgotten, swine of an American," he roared suddenly, and in his hand was an ugly looking automatic. He flung back his robe and Noork saw the dress uniform of a general. Shortly after midday Noork felt the oozy slime of the marshy lowlands of the mainland beneath his paddle and the dugout ran ashore in the grassy inlet for which they had been heading. His palms were blistered and the heavy robes he yet wore were soaked with sweat. "Once we reach the jungle," he told the girl, "off come these robes. I am broiled alive." Suddenly Noork froze in his tracks. He thrust the girl behind him. "Misty Ones!" he hissed to Rold. "They crouch among the reeds. They carry nets and clubs to trap us." Rold turned back toward the boat with Noork and Sarna close at his heels. But the Misty Ones were upon them and by sheer numbers they bore them to the ground. Noork's mightier muscles smashed more than one hooded face but in the end he too lay smothered beneath the nets and bodies of the enemy. Text:
on Sekk, the wily scientist preferring the lesser gravity of this fertile world to that of the lifeless Moon in the event that he returned again to Earth, but Dietrich's spacer had crashed. Two words linked Noork with the past, the two words that the Vasads had slurred into his name: New York. And the battered wrist watch, its crystal and hands gone, were all that remained of his Earthly garb. Noork paddled the long flat dugout strongly away from the twilight shore toward the shadowy loom of the central island. Though he could not remember ever having held a paddle before he handled the ungainly blade well. After a time the clumsy prow of the craft rammed into a yielding cushion of mud, and Noork pulled the dugout out of the water into the roofing shelter of a clump of drooping trees growing at the water's edge. Sword in hand he pushed inward from the shore and ended with a smothered exclamation against an unseen wall. Trees grew close up to the wall and a moment later he had climbed out along a horizontal branch beyond the wall's top, and was lowering his body with the aid of a braided leather rope to the ground beyond. He was in a cultivated field his feet and hands told him. And perhaps half a mile away, faintly illumined by torches and red clots of bonfires, towered a huge weathered white skull! Another slave was working in a nearby field, his crude wooden plow pulled by two sweating Vasads, but he was not watching when Rold abruptly faded from view. Noork was sweating with the weight of two cloaks and the airlessness of the vision shield as they crossed the field toward his rope, but he had no wish to discard them yet. The tinted shield had revealed that dozens of the Misty Ones were stationed about the wall to guard against the escape of the slaves. They came to the wall and to Noork's great joy found the rope hanging as he had left it. He climbed the wall first and then with Rold helping from below, drew Sarna to his side. A moment later saw the three of them climbing along the limb to the bole of the tree and so to the jungle matted ground outside the wall. "Will we hide here in the trees until night?" asked the girl's full voice. Noork held aside a mossy creeper until the girl had passed. "I think not," he said. "The Misty Ones are continually passing from the island to the shore. We are Misty Ones to any that watch from the wall. So we will paddle boldly across the water." "My brother said that we should no longer make slaves of the captured Zurans from the other valleys." Noork smiled. "I am glad he is your brother," he said simply. All but one of them. The arrow had pierced a vital portion of this Misty One's body. He fell and moved no more. A moment later Noork was ripping the stained cloak and hood from the fallen creature, curious to learn what ghastly brute-thing hid beneath them. His lip curled at what he saw. The Misty One was almost like himself. His skin was not so golden as that of the other men of Zuran, and his forehead was low and retreating in a bestial fashion. Upon his body there was more hair, and his face was made hideous with swollen colored scars that formed an irregular design. He wore a sleeveless tunic of light green and his only weapons were two long knives and a club. "So," said Noork, "the men of the island prey upon their own kind. And the Temple of Uzdon in the lake is guarded by cowardly warriors like this." Noork shrugged his shoulders and set off at a mile-devouring pace down the game trail toward the lake where the Temple of the Skull and its unseen guardians lay. [Transcriber's Note: This etext was produced from Planet Stories Summer 1945. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.] Beyond earth swings that airless pocked mass of fused rock and gray volcanic dust that we know as Luna. Of this our naked eyes assure us. But of the smaller satellite, hidden forever from the mundane view by Luna's bulk, we know little. Small is Sekk, that second moon, less than five hundred miles in diameter, but the period of its revolution is thirty two hours, and its meaner mass retains a breathable atmosphere. There is life on Sekk, life that centers around the sunken star-shaped cavity where an oval lake gleams softly in the depths. And the eleven radiating tips of the starry abyss are valleys green with jungle growth. In one of those green valleys the white savage that the Vasads called Noork squatted in the ample crotch of a jungle giant and watched the trail forty feet below. For down there moved alertly a golden skinned girl, her only weapons a puny polished bow of yellow wood and a sheathed dagger. Text:
room with unpleasing echoes. Noork grinned. From the floor beside the fatter of the two men, the guard who did not snore, he took a club. Twice he struck and the gurgling sound changed to a steady deep breathing. Noork knew that now the two guards would not give the alarm for several hours. Thoughtfully he looked about the room. There were several of the hooded cloaks hanging from pegs wedged into the crevices of the chamber's wall, their outlines much plainer here in the artificial light of the flickering torch. Noork shed his own blood-stained robe quickly and donned one of the others. The cloaks were rather bulky and so he could carry but two others, rolled up, beneath his own protective covering. The matter of his disguise thus taken care of he dragged the two bodies from the stairway and hid them beneath their own fouled robes in the chamber of the sleeping guards. Not until then did he hurry on down the stone steps toward the prison pit where Tholon Sarna, the golden girl, was held prisoner. The steps opened into a dimly lit cavern. Pools of foul black water dotted the uneven floor and reflected back faintly the light of the two sputtering torches beside the entrance. One corner of the cavern was walled off, save for a narrow door of interlocking brass strips, and toward this Noork made his way. He stood beside the door. "Sarna," he called softly, "Tholon Sarna." "All the young female slaves are caged together in the pit beneath the Skull. When the sun is directly overhead the High Priest will choose one of them for sacrifice to mighty Uzdon, most potent of all gods. And with the dawning of the next day the chosen one will be bound across the altar before great Uzdon's image and her heart torn from her living breast." The slave's mismatched eyes, one blue and the other brown, lifted from his work. "Tholon Sarna is in the pit beneath the Temple with the other female slaves. And the Misty Ones stand guard over the entrance to the temple pits." "It is enough," said Noork. "I will go to rescue her now. Be prepared to join us as we return. I will have a robe for you if all goes well." "If you are captured," cried Rold nervously, "you will not tell them I talked with you?" Noork laughed. "You never saw me," he told the slave. Text:
your guards, then." The priest laughed. "We also have robes of invisibility," he said, "and the sacred window of Uzdon before our eyes." He snarled suddenly at the silent figure of the white man. "Down on your knees, guard, and show me your face before I kill you!" Noork raised his sword. "Take my hood off if you dare, priest," he offered. The burly priest's answer was a bellow of rage and a lunge forward of his sword arm. Their swords clicked together and slid apart with the velvety smoothness of bronze on bronze. Noork's blade bit a chunk from the priest's conical shield, and in return received a slashing cut that drew blood from left shoulder to elbow. The fighting grew more furious as the priest pressed the attack. He was a skilled swordsman and only the superior agility of the white man's legs kept Noork away from that darting priestly blade. Even so his robe was slashed in a dozen places and blood reddened his bronzed body. Once he slipped in a puddle of foul cavern water and only by the slightest of margins did he escape death by the priest's weapon. The priest was tiring rapidly, however. The soft living of the temple, and the rich wines and over-cooked meats that served to pad his paunch so well with fat, now served to rob him of breath. For between the hairy quarter-ton beast men of the jungles of Sekk and the golden men of the valley cities who enslaved them there was eternal war. A growl rumbled deep in the hairy half-man's chest. He could see no enemy and yet the scent grew stronger with every breath. "You hunt too near the lake," called a voice. "The demons of the water will trap you." Ud's great nostrils quivered. He tasted the odor of a friend mingled with that of a strange Zuran. He squatted. "It's Noork," he grunted. "Why do I not see you?" "I have stolen the skin of a demon," answered the invisible man. "Go to Gurn. Tell him to fear the demons no longer. Tell him the Misty Ones can be trapped and skinned." "Why you want their skins?" Ud scratched his hairy gray skull. "Go to save Gurn's ..." and here Noork was stumped for words. "To save his father's woman woman," he managed at last. "Father's woman woman called Sarna." And the misty blob of nothingness was gone again, its goal now the marshy lowlands that extended upward perhaps a thousand feet from the jungle's ragged fringe to end at last in the muddy shallows of the Lake of Uzdon. And then Doctor Von Mark cursed as the gun dropped from his nerveless fingers and his hands clawed weakly at the arrow buried in his wide belly. He stumbled backward. Arrows rained from the mistiness that had closed in about Von Mark and his men. The men from Wari, their faces unshielded, fell like flies. In a moment those yet alive had taken to their heels, and Noork felt invisible fingers tearing at the nets that bound him. As he rose to his feet the robed figure let its misty covering drop aside. A handsome golden-skinned warrior stood revealed. "Gurn!" cried Noork. A glad cry came from the throat of Tholon Sarna as she saw her brother. And then she crept closer to Noork's side as the invisible mantles of Gurn's loyal Vasads opened to reveal the hairy beast men they concealed. Rold whimpered fearfully. "The message that Ud carried to me was good," laughed Gurn. "The Misty Ones skin easily. We were trapping the Misty Ones as they came across the lake," he looked at the dying Von Mark, "as were these others. Soon we would have come to your rescue, Noork, my friend." "Lucky I escaped first," Noork told him. "The priests of Uzdon would have trapped you. To them the Misty Ones are visible." He picked up the fallen vision shield that lay beside their feet. Text:
I will complete my checking of the gardens." Noork waited until the old man was gone before he descended from the tree. He walked along the row until he reached the slave's bent back, and he knew by the sudden tightening of the man's shoulder muscles that his presence was known. He looked down and saw that his feet made clear-cut depressions in the soft rich soil of the field. "Continue to work," he said to the young man. "Do not be too surprised at what I am about to tell you, Rold." He paused and watched the golden man's rather stupid face intently. "I am not a Misty One," Noork said. "I killed the owner of this strange garment I wear yesterday on the mainland. I have come to rescue the girl, Tholon Sarna, of whom you spoke." Rold's mouth hung open but his hard blunt fingers continued to work. "The Misty Ones, then," he said slowly, "are not immortal demons!" He nodded his long-haired head. "They are but men. They too can die." "If you will help me, Rold," said Noork, "to rescue the girl and escape from the island I will take you along." Rold was slow in answering. He had been born on the island and yet his people were from the valley city of Konto. He knew that they would welcome the news that the Misty Ones were not demons. And the girl from the enemy city of Grath was beautiful. Perhaps she would love him for helping to rescue her

The upper levels, then, were forbidden to the slaves and common citizens of the island. As he circled the curving inner wall a foul dank odor reached his sensitive nostrils, and his eyes searched for its origin. He found it there just before him, the opening that gave way to a descending flight of clammy stone steps. He darted toward the door and from nowhere two short swords rose to bar his way. "None are to pass save the priests," spoke a voice from nowhere gruffly. "The High Priest knows that we of the temple guards covet the most beautiful of the slave women, but we are not to see them until the sacrifice is chosen." Noork moved backward a pace. He grumbled something inaudible and drew his sword. Before him the two swords slowly drew aside. In that instant Noork attacked. His keen sword, whetted to razor sharpness on abrasive bits of rock, bit through the hidden neck and shoulder of the guard on his right hand, and with the same forward impetus of attack he smashed into the body of the startled guard on his left. His sword had wrenched from his hand as it jammed into the bony structure of the decapitated Misty One's shoulder, and now both his hands sought the throat of the guard. He moved swiftly to cross the wide stone-slabbed entry within the jaws, and a moment later was looking down into a sunken bowl whose rocky floor was a score of feet below where he stood. Now he saw the central raised altar where the gleam of precious stones and cunningly worked metalâ€”gold, silver and brassâ€”vied with the faded garish colors of the draperies beneath it. And the other bird, for which Noork had been searching when he came upon the golden-skinned girl, was from another world also. Perhaps, thought Noork, the bird had come from the same valley that had once been his home. He would find the bird and perhaps then he could remember better who he had been. system_prompt:
You are evaluating the response generated by a RAG system.

The query was:
What is the plot of the story?

The response was:
Captain Dietrich, who is from America, has been hunting an evil man. After the evil man is dead and his native valley is safe, Captain Dietrich wishes to live in peace with Gurn and Gurn's sister in the jungle. Noork addresses Doctor Von Mark as Captain Dietrich.

Based on the query and the generated response, provide a detailed explanation of how the response can be improved. Focus on aspects like completeness, accuracy, relevance, clarity, and whether it fully addresses the question asked. Consider whether the response is well-structured, directly addresses the question, provides sufficient detail, and maintains factual consistency.
user_prompt: Please evaluate the response and provide improvement suggestions.
llm_response:
## Evaluation of the RAG Response:

The RAG system's response provides a fragmented and somewhat confusing summary of a plot. While it touches upon key characters and a central conflict, it lacks coherence, detail, and a clear narrative arc.

Here's a breakdown of its strengths and weaknesses:

**Strengths:**

*   **Identifies key characters:** It mentions Captain Dietrich, Gurn, Gurn's sister, and Doctor Von Mark (though the connection to Dietrich is unclear).
*   **Mentions a central conflict:** The "hunting an evil man" and the subsequent desire for peace suggest a core struggle.
*   **Includes a setting:** The "native valley" and "jungle" provide some environmental context.

**Weaknesses:**

*   **Incomplete Plot:** The response feels like a collection of disconnected sentences rather than a cohesive plot summary. It doesn't explain *why* Captain Dietrich is hunting the evil man, *how* he hunts him, the significance of the "native valley" being safe, or the details of his desire to live in peace.
*   **Lack of Clarity and Coherence:**
    *   The sentence "After the evil man is dead and his native valley is safe, Captain Dietrich wishes to live in peace with Gurn and Gurn's sister in the jungle" feels abrupt. It doesn't explain Gurn and his sister's role or how they become involved.
    *   The final sentence, "Noork addresses Doctor Von Mark as Captain Dietrich," is very confusing. It introduces a new character ("Noork") and a confusing interaction without any context. It's unclear if Doctor Von Mark *is* Captain Dietrich, or if Noork is mistaken, or if this is a separate event entirely. This sentence significantly detracts from the overall clarity.
*   **Ambiguity:**
    *   Who is the "evil man"? What makes him evil?
    *   What is the relationship between Captain Dietrich and Doctor Von Mark? Are they the same person? Is Von Mark an antagonist?
    *   What is the significance of Gurn and his sister? Are they allies, dependents, or something else?
*   **Insufficient Detail:** A plot summary should ideally cover the inciting incident, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution (or at least the main components of these). This response only offers a very high-level, and somewhat disjointed, overview.
*   **Potentially Inaccurate (due to ambiguity):** The confusion surrounding Doctor Von Mark and Captain Dietrich raises questions about the accuracy of the presented information.

## Improvement Suggestions:

To create a truly helpful and accurate plot summary, the RAG system should aim for the following:

1.  **Establish a Clear Narrative Flow:** The summary needs to present events in a logical, chronological order. Sentences should connect smoothly, guiding the reader through the story's progression.

2.  **Provide Context and Background:**
    *   Explain Captain Dietrich's motivations for hunting the evil man. What is their history? What specific evil deeds has the man committed?
    *   Clarify the relationship between Captain Dietrich and Doctor Von Mark. Are they the same person? If not, what is their connection? Is Von Mark an adversary, an ally, or a misidentified individual?
    *   Introduce Gurn and his sister earlier and explain their role in the story. Are they helping Dietrich, are they natives of the valley, or are they simply people he encounters?

3.  **Elaborate on Key Events:**
    *   Describe the hunt for the evil man and its significance.
    *   Explain *why* the "native valley" is important and what happens after it's safe.
    *   Detail Captain Dietrich's desire for peace. What does this peace entail? What are the challenges to achieving it?

4.  **Resolve Ambiguities:** The confusing statement about Noork and Doctor Von Mark needs to be either integrated into the main plot with proper context or removed if it's an unrelated detail that derails the summary. If it's a crucial plot point, it needs to be explained clearly.

5.  **Maintain Factual Consistency:** Ensure that characters and their identities are presented consistently throughout the summary.

6.  **Structure for Readability:** Use paragraph breaks to separate different stages of the plot or distinct thematic elements.

**Example of an Improved Response (Hypothetical, based on inferred plot elements):**

"The story follows Captain Dietrich, an American who embarks on a perilous quest to hunt down an evil man responsible for great suffering. After a protracted struggle, Captain Dietrich ultimately succeeds in defeating this antagonist, bringing peace to the man's native valley. Having achieved his objective, Captain Dietrich yearns for a tranquil life and intends to settle in the jungle alongside Gurn and his sister. However, his pursuit of peace is complicated by events such as a character named Noork who mistakenly identifies Doctor Von Mark as Captain Dietrich, hinting at potential lingering dangers or misunderstandings."

**In summary, the original response is a collection of plot points rather than a plot summary. It needs to be fleshed out with context, chronological order, and clear explanations of character relationships and motivations to be truly effective.**

llm_response:
Critique:

The current retrieval plan demonstrates a significant misunderstanding of how to build a coherent narrative. The core issue is the scattered and disjointed nature of the retrieved information, leading to a fragmented understanding of the plot.

1.  **Inconsistent Focus:** The plan jumps between exploring "conflict" relationships (Iteration 1), then "adversarial" relationships (Iteration 2), and finally "collaborative" relationships (Iteration 3). While all are relevant to plot, the transitions lack a clear strategy to synthesize these into a single narrative arc. The system doesn't seem to prioritize or connect these different types of relationships to build a chronological story.
2.  **Lack of Strategic Depth:** The plan relies heavily on keyword searches (e.g., "conflict," "adversarial," "collaborative") without a deeper understanding of plot progression. It fails to identify key plot drivers like character motivations, central conflicts, or turning points. For instance, after identifying "adversarial" relationships involving Noork, Von Mark, and the Misty Ones, the plan shifts to "collaborative" relationships among Noork, Sarna, and Gurn without explicitly linking *how* these collaborative efforts directly address or resolve the previously identified adversarial conflicts.
3.  **Inefficient Exploration:** The exploration of "adversarial" relationships in Iteration 2 identified many key characters and conflicts (Von Mark, Noork, Misty Ones, Sarna, Captain Dietrich). However, the subsequent "collaborative" exploration in Iteration 3, while finding useful character interactions, doesn't clearly build upon the established adversarial landscape. It seems to rediscover or re-contextualize characters without a clear goal of resolving the central conflicts.
4.  **Missed Opportunities for Synthesis:** The system retrieves a wealth of information about Noork's various relationships and struggles. However, it doesn't appear to be actively trying to weave these into a cohesive storyline. For example, the adversarial relationships involving Von Mark and the reveal of Noork as Captain Dietrich in Iteration 2 are not directly followed up by exploring how his collaborative efforts with Sarna, Gurn, etc., contribute to confronting Von Mark or resolving his amnesia.

Feedback for Improvement:

1.  **Prioritize Narrative Threads:** Instead of exploring relationship types sequentially, the plan should identify key narrative threads (e.g., Noork's quest for freedom, the conflict with Von Mark, the mystery of Noork's identity, the rescue of Sarna) and strategically retrieve information to flesh out each thread.
2.  **Build Connections Between Relationship Types:** The system needs to actively connect different types of relationships. For example, how do the "collaborative" efforts of Noork and his allies (Iteration 3) impact the "adversarial" conflicts with Von Mark and the Misty Ones (Iterations 1 & 2)? The plan should aim to bridge these.
3.  **Focus on Character Arcs and Plot Progression:** The plan should aim to track character development and plot progression. For instance, after establishing Noork as Captain Dietrich with amnesia and identifying Von Mark as the antagonist, subsequent steps should focus on retrieving information that explains how this conflict resolves, how Noork regains his memory, and how Sarna is ultimately saved or what her role becomes.
4.  **Strategic Node Exploration:** Once key characters and conflicts are identified (e.g., Noork, Sarna, Von Mark, Misty Ones), the plan should strategically explore their direct connections and interactions related to the central plot points, rather than broadly searching for relationship types. It should ask: "How does this character's action in a collaborative setting affect the adversarial conflict?"

You are evaluating the prompt used for retrieval planning in an agentic GraphRAG system. 

The system works this way:
The system starts from an input text and a fixed query. An LLM selects the hyperparameters (chunk size). The input text (where the information is located) is split into chunks based on the chosen chunk size. For each chunk, an LLM is used to extract a graph. The graphs are then merged. An LLM agent has access to a set of functions to explore the graph (the set is fixed and includes queries on entities and relations based on type or name, access to neighbors, community detection, and identification of central nodes). The context obtained from the exploration is then passed to an LLM together with the query. The LLM generates an answer.

Critique:

The retrieval plans consistently fail to build a coherent understanding of the story's plot. Each iteration appears to explore relationships in isolation without a clear strategy to connect them into a narrative.

1.  **Lack of Narrative Cohesion:** The plans jump between different types of entities and relationships (e.g., "Person" nodes, then "Captain Dietrich's" neighbors, then again exploring neighbors) without a clear progression that builds a story. There's no apparent strategy to link discovered characters and events into a chronological or causal sequence.
2.  **Shallow Information Gathering:** The plans focus on discovering *what* connections exist (e.g., neighbors of a person) but not *how* these connections contribute to the plot. For instance, simply finding neighbors of "Captain Dietrich" doesn't inherently explain his role in the plot or the story's events. The plans don't show an intent to synthesize information to understand motivations, conflicts, or resolutions.
3.  **Inefficient Exploration Strategy:** The approach of broadly searching for node types and then exploring neighbors of a single identified node lacks a targeted strategy. If "Captain Dietrich" is identified, subsequent steps should focus on exploring relationships relevant to his role in the plot (e.g., "interacted with," "commands," "attacked by") rather than just general neighbors.
4.  **No Focus on Plot Drivers:** The plans do not identify or track key plot drivers such as central conflicts, character motivations, turning points, or resolutions. The query is about the "plot," yet the retrieval steps do not demonstrate an attempt to map out the story's arc, character arcs, or the core conflict.

Feedback for Improvement:

1.  **Define Narrative Threads:** Identify potential narrative threads (e.g., character quests, major conflicts, mysteries) early on and focus retrieval on gathering information that fleshes out these specific threads.
2.  **Prioritize Relationship Significance:** When exploring nodes, prioritize relationship types that are most likely to advance the plot (e.g., "killed," "rescued," "fought," "attacked") over generic ones.
3.  **Connect Discovered Information:** After retrieving information, the next step should actively aim to connect new findings to previously established plot points or characters. Ask: "How does this new information relate to what we already know about the plot?"
4.  **Focus on Causal Chains:** Structure retrieval to uncover causal relationships. For example, if a character is "attacked," the next logical step is to find out *who* attacked them and *why*, and what the consequences were. This helps build a cause-and-effect narrative.

Here's a concise summary of the critique and feedback, highlighting the key areas for improvement:

**Critique Summary:**

*   **Lack of Narrative Cohesion:** Plans explore isolated relationships without building a story.
*   **Shallow Information Gathering:** Focus on *what* connections exist, not *how* they drive the plot.
*   **Inefficient Exploration:** Generic neighbor searches instead of targeted, plot-relevant relationships.
*   **No Focus on Plot Drivers:** Fails to identify or track central conflicts, motivations, or turning points.

**Feedback for Improvement:**

1.  **Define Narrative Threads:** Identify and focus on specific plot threads (quests, conflicts, mysteries).
2.  **Prioritize Relationship Significance:** Favor relationship types that actively advance the plot (e.g., "killed," "fought") over generic ones.
3.  **Connect Discovered Information:** Actively link new findings to existing plot points and characters.
4.  **Focus on Causal Chains:** Uncover cause-and-effect relationships to build a coherent narrative arc.

Here is the optimized system prompt:

You are an expert GraphRAG retrieval planner. Your goal is to construct a sequence of retrieval steps that effectively uncovers the core plot of a given story represented in a knowledge graph.

**Your retrieval plans must prioritize narrative cohesion and plot understanding.** Avoid isolated explorations and aim to build a coherent story arc.

**Key Principles for Planning:**

1.  **Identify and Pursue Narrative Threads:**
    *   Begin by identifying potential central conflicts, character journeys, mysteries, or key events.
    *   Structure your retrieval steps to flesh out these identified threads. For example, if a conflict is identified, prioritize retrieving information about its participants, causes, and consequences.

2.  **Prioritize Plot-Advancing Relationships:**
    *   When selecting `graph_search` or `node_retrieval` functions, strongly favor relationship types that are inherently plot-driving.
    *   Examples of high-priority relationships: `interacted_with` (if contextually relevant to conflict/resolution), `attacked`, `killed`, `rescued`, `betrayed`, `allied_with`, `discovered`, `caused`, `led_to`, `motivates`.
    *   Minimize reliance on generic relationships like `neighbor_of` or `related_to` unless they directly serve to connect critical plot elements or characters.

3.  **Connect and Synthesize Information:**
    *   After each retrieval step, critically assess the new information in the context of what has already been retrieved.
    *   The *next* retrieval step should explicitly aim to connect the new findings to existing narrative elements. Ask: "How does this new information build upon or alter our understanding of the plot so far?" or "Who or what is involved in this new development, and how do they connect to previously identified characters/events?"

4.  **Uncover Causal Chains and Story Arcs:**
    *   Structure your plans to reveal cause-and-effect relationships. If an event occurs, plan to retrieve its preceding causes and subsequent consequences.
    *   Aim to map out the story's progression: inciting incident, rising action, climax, falling action, resolution. Your retrieval steps should reflect this progression.

5.  **Targeted Node Exploration:**
    *   If a specific entity (e.g., a character, location, or event) is identified as central, focus subsequent retrieval on relationships *critical to its role in the plot*.
    *   For example, if "Captain Dietrich" is identified, don't just retrieve generic neighbors. Instead, retrieve who he `commanded`, who `attacked` him, what he `discovered`, or what event he `participated_in`.

**Function Usage Guidelines:**

*   `graph_search(query, k)`: Use this to find relevant nodes or relationships based on a descriptive query focusing on plot elements. Ensure your `query` is specific and hints at narrative significance.
*   `node_retrieval(node_id, relationship_types)`: Use this to explore specific nodes. Crucially, **always specify `relationship_types` that are plot-relevant** based on the principles above. Avoid calling this without specific, plot-focused `relationship_types`.
*   `subgraph_retrieval(node_ids, relationship_types)`: Use this to retrieve a focused subgraph around key plot elements. Again, prioritize plot-advancing `relationship_types`.

**Output Format:**

Generate a JSON list of retrieval steps. Each step should be a dictionary with a `function` key (e.g., "graph_search", "node_retrieval") and `parameters` key containing the arguments for that function. Ensure your parameters reflect the planning principles outlined above.

**Example of desired planning logic:**

*Initial Query: "What is the central conflict in the story?"*

*Step 1: `graph_search(query="central conflict in the story", k=1)`* -> Identifies a conflict node "The Great Betrayal".
*Step 2: `node_retrieval(node_id="The Great Betrayal", relationship_types=["involved_party", "cause", "consequence"])`* -> Retrieves characters involved and the immediate outcomes.
*Step 3: Based on Step 2 results (e.g., character "Elara"), plan to explore Elara's motivations and actions related to the conflict: `node_retrieval(node_id="Elara", relationship_types=["betrayed", "motivated_by", "took_action_against"])`*

**Begin planning the retrieval steps.**

The system starts from an input text and a fixed query. An LLM selects the hyperparameters (chunk size). llm_response:
The current prompt for graph construction is overly focused on extracting granular details, leading to a proliferation of highly specific and often redundant relationship types. This results in a noisy graph that obscures the main narrative threads needed to answer questions about the plot.

**Critique:**

1.  **Excessive Granularity and Redundancy in Relationships:** The prompt encourages the extraction of every minute interaction, resulting in numerous low-frequency, overlapping relationship types (e.g., multiple "attack" variants, similar "travel" relations). This creates a "long-tail" distribution of relationships, making it difficult for an agent to discern significant plot points from minor details.
2.  **Lack of Thematic Grouping:** The prompt does not guide the LLM to categorize relationships thematically. Consequently, relationships related to core plot elements like conflict, movement, or character motivation are scattered and not aggregated, hindering the formation of a coherent narrative understanding.
3.  **Entity-Relationship Imbalance:** While entities are extracted, the relationships often fail to capture the *narrative significance* of their connections, especially for "Person" entities. The prompt's emphasis on extracting *all* relationships rather than *plot-relevant* ones leads to many superficial connections.
4.  **Potential for Information Overload:** The sheer volume of fine-grained relationships overwhelms the graph, making it computationally expensive and conceptually challenging for an agent to navigate and synthesize information to answer a plot-related query.

**Feedback for Improvement:**

1.  **Prioritize Thematic Relationships:** Modify the prompt to explicitly ask for relationships that represent core plot drivers: conflict, goals, alliances, motivations, key events, and character roles.
2.  **Encourage Relationship Generalization:** Instruct the LLM to group similar specific actions under broader, more abstract relationship types (e.g., "CONFLICT" instead of "attacks," "fights," "battles"; "MOVEMENT" instead of "travels to," "enters," "lands on").
3.  **Focus on Narrative Relevance:** Emphasize extracting relationships that contribute directly to the unfolding of the story and character development, rather than every factual link.
4.  **Define Key Entity Properties:** For important entities (like "Person"), guide the LLM to extract properties that are crucial for understanding their role in the plot (e.g., "goal," "motivation," "role in conflict").

llm_response:
The current system prompt is **overly focused on granular detail**, leading to:

1.  **Relationship Proliferation & Redundancy:** It extracts too many specific, low-frequency relationships (e.g., "hands object to," "looks at briefly") that overlap significantly, creating a noisy graph. This "long-tail" problem obscures major plot threads.
2.  **Lack of Thematic Abstraction:** The prompt doesn't guide the LLM to generalize relationships into broader thematic categories (e.g., "CONFLICT," "GOAL_PURSUIT," "MOVEMENT"). This prevents the graph from representing high-level plot structures.
3.  **Superficial Entity Connections:** While entities are identified, the relationships often capture trivial interactions rather than those crucial to character arcs or plot progression, especially for "Person" entities. The emphasis isn't on *narrative significance*.
4.  **Information Overload:** The sheer volume of fine-grained, non-aggregated relationships makes the graph computationally burdensome and difficult for downstream agents to navigate for plot understanding.

**Feedback for Improvement:**

1.  **Prioritize Thematic Relationships:** Explicitly instruct the LLM to identify and extract relationships representing core plot drivers: conflict, goals, motivations, alliances, key events, and character roles.
2.  **Encourage Relationship Generalization:** Direct the LLM to group similar specific actions under broader, more abstract relationship types. Provide examples.
3.  **Focus on Narrative Relevance:** Emphasize extracting connections that directly contribute to the unfolding of the story, character development, and plot progression, not every factual link.
4.  **Extract Key Entity Properties:** For critical entities (especially "Person"), guide the LLM to extract properties vital for plot comprehension (e.g., "primary goal," "key motivation," "role in conflict," "status").

---

**Optimized System Prompt:**

You are an expert graph constructor for a GraphRAG system. Your task is to extract key entities and their relationships from narrative text, focusing on building a coherent and semantically rich knowledge graph that captures the core plot and character dynamics.

**Extraction Guidelines:**

1.  **Identify Core Entities:** Extract key entities such as `Person`, `Location`, `Organization`, `Event`, `Artifact`, and `Concept`.
2.  **Prioritize Thematic Relationships:** Focus on extracting relationships that represent the primary drivers of the narrative. Generalize and abstract relationships where appropriate. Use the following high-level relationship types:
    *   `PART_OF`: Hierarchical or containment relationships (e.g., Chapter `PART_OF` Book, Room `PART_OF` House).
    *   `LOCATED_AT`: Physical or metaphorical location.
    *   `PARTICIPATES_IN`: Characters or entities involved in an Event.
    *   `CAUSES` / `ENABLES`: Causal links between events or actions.
    *   `CONFLICT_WITH`: Antagonistic relationships between entities (individuals, groups, ideas).
    *   `ALLIED_WITH`: Cooperative or supportive relationships.
    *   `HAS_GOAL`: The objective or aim of a `Person` or `Organization`.
    *   `HAS_MOTIVATION`: The underlying reason for a `Person`'s actions or goals.
    *   `USES`: An entity utilizing another entity (e.g., Person `USES` Artifact).
    *   `TRAVELS_TO`: Movement between locations.
    *   `INTERACTS_WITH`: General interaction, use sparingly for plot-crucial exchanges not covered by other types.
    *   `RELATED_TO`: For concepts or abstract connections.
3.  **Extract Narrative-Significant Properties:** For `Person` entities, extract key properties that define their role and development in the narrative:
    *   `role_in_plot`: (e.g., "Protagonist," "Antagonist," "Mentor," "Supporting Character")
    *   `primary_goal`: The main objective driving their actions.
    *   `key_motivation`: The core reason behind their goal or actions.
    *   `status`: (e.g., "Alive," "Deceased," "Injured," "Missing")
    *   `allegiance`: Group affiliation or loyalty.
4.  **Generalize Specific Actions:** If a specific action strongly implies a broader thematic relationship, use the thematic type.
    *   *Example:* If Person A "attacks" Person B, extract `CONFLICT_WITH(Person A, Person B)`.
    *   *Example:* If Person A "travels from City X to City Y," extract `TRAVELS_TO(Person A, City Y)` and potentially `LOCATED_AT(Person A, City X)` at the start.
    *   *Example:* If Person A "wants to find the treasure," extract `HAS_GOAL(Person A, Find Treasure Event)`.
5.  **Focus on Plot Relevance:** Prioritize relationships and properties that are essential for understanding the main storyline, character motivations, conflicts, and resolutions. Avoid extracting every minor detail or interaction unless it directly impacts the plot.
6.  **Output Format:** Present the extracted information as a list of nodes (entities with properties) and edges (relationships between entities).

**Example Input:**

"Elara, the determined protagonist, sought the ancient artifact to save her village from the encroaching darkness. She traveled from the Whispering Woods to the Crystal Caves, guided by the old hermit's cryptic map. The Shadow Lord, her sworn enemy, also desired the artifact for his nefarious plans."

**Example Output Structure:**

```json
{
  "nodes": [
    {"id": "Elara", "type": "Person", "properties": {"role_in_plot": "Protagonist", "primary_goal": "Save village", "key_motivation": "Protect village"}},
    {"id": "Village", "type": "Location"},
    {"id": "Darkness", "type": "Concept"},
    {"id": "Whispering Woods", "type": "Location"},
    {"id": "Crystal Caves", "type": "Location"},
    {"id": "Hermit", "type": "Person", "properties": {"role_in_plot": "Mentor"}},
    {"id": "Map", "type": "Artifact"},
    {"id": "Shadow Lord", "type": "Person", "properties": {"role_in_plot": "Antagonist", "primary_goal": "Obtain artifact"}},
    {"id": "Ancient Artifact", "type": "Artifact"}
  ],
  "edges": [
    {"source": "Elara", "target": "Village", "label": "PARTICIPATES_IN", "relation": "Protects"}, // Adjusted for clarity
    {"source": "Darkness", "target": "Village", "label": "CONFLICT_WITH"},
    {"source": "Elara", "target": "Whispering Woods", "label": "LOCATED_AT"},
    {"source": "Elara", "target": "Crystal Caves", "label": "TRAVELS_TO"},
    {"source": "Hermit", "target": "Map", "label": "GAVE"}, // Could be simplified to RELATED_TO or USES if Map is key
    {"source": "Hermit", "target": "Elara", "label": "GUIDED"}, // Could be ALLIED_WITH or RELATED_TO
    {"source": "Elara", "target": "Ancient Artifact", "label": "HAS_GOAL"},
    {"source": "Shadow Lord", "target": "Ancient Artifact", "label": "HAS_GOAL"},
    {"source": "Shadow Lord", "target": "Elara", "label": "CONFLICT_WITH"}
  ]
}
```
